titlestmt.titleproper: Peter Fallon - Gallery Press collection, circa 1967-1998
titlestmt.author: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University

address.addressline: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

did.unittitle: Peter Fallon - Gallery Press collection, circa 1967-1998
did.physdesc: 124.5 linear ft.(224 boxes) and 127 oversized papers (OP)
did.abstract: Personal and literary papers of Irish poet and publisher Peter Fallon, as well as the archives of the Gallery Press.
did.repository: Emory UniversityManuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Collection stored off-site. Researchers must contact MARBL in advance to access this collection.
Subseries 2.2. and Series 8: Letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

userestrict.head: Terms Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: All requests subject to limitations noted in departmental policies on reproduction. Information on copyright (literary rights) available from repository.

prefercite.head: Citation
prefercite.p: [after identification of item(s)], Peter Fallon - Gallery Press collection, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University.

processinfo.head: Processing
processinfo.p: Processed by Katie Long, Robin Connor, Ryan Lynch, Student Processing Assistants, 2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical or Historical Note
bioghist.p: Peter Fallon, poet, editor and publisher, was born in Germany in 1951 but spent his early years on a farm in County Meath, Ireland. He graduated in 1975 with a B.A. in English Language and Literature and an H.Dip. Ed from Trinity College. In 1970, at the age of eighteen, he founded The Gallery Press that has published poems and plays by the Ireland’s finest established and emerging authors. The Gallery Press is recognised as the pre-eminent literary publishing house in Ireland. Among the writers it publishes are John Banville, Ciaran Carson, Medbh McGuckian, Derek Mahon, John Montague, Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill, and the playwright Brian Friel. The press has also published books by Paul Durcan, Seamus Heaney, and Paul Muldoon.

Fallon first began touring the United States, Europe, and Japan in 1972 and has since given readings, lectures and workshops at over one hundred colleges and universities. In 1976-1977 he served as poet-in-residence at Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and in 1979 Fallon was the International Poet-in-Residence in the Indiana Public Schools. Fallon acted as fiction editor at the O'Brien press from 1980-1985. The National Arts Council of Ireland awarded Fallon an Arts Council bursary in 1981. In 1990 he and Derek Mahon edited The Penguin Book of Contemporary Irish Poetry. Peter Fallon's own collections of poems include The Speaking Stones, Winter Work, The News and Weather, Eye to Eye, and News Of the World: Selected and New Poems. A selection of his poems, News of the World: Selected Poems, was published in the United States by Wake Forest University Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the records of The Gallery Press and Peter Fallon from ca. 1967-1998. The records include literary manuscripts, correspondence files, subject files, printed material, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: (1) Literary manuscripts, (2) Correspondence, (3) Peter Fallon, (4) Subject files, (5) Printed material, (6) Photographs, (7) Ephemera, and (8) Unprocessed additions.

separatedmaterial.head: Related Materials in This Repository
separatedmaterial.p: Ciaran Carson papers, Ted Hughes papers, Michael Longley papers, Medbh McGuckian papers, Derek Mahon papers, Paul Muldoon papers, Desmond O'Grady papers, Frank Ormsby papers, and James Simmons papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series contains files relating to authors who have published works through the Gallery Press (1969-1988), Gallery Press in conjunction with Deerfield Press, O'Brien Press (1980-1980), and Oldcastle Enterprises/After Hours Books. The files may include biographical information on the author, correspondence, manuscripts and typescripts of their works, and page proofs and mock-ups. Additional correspondence may be found in Literary Correspondence (Subseries 2.2) and press and publicity materials may be found in Publicity files on authors (Subseries 5.1).

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: (1.1) Gallery Press author files, (1.2) Gallery Press submission files, (1.3) Deerfield Press author files, (1.4) O'Brien Press author files, and (1.5) Oldcastle Enterprises/After Hours Books author files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Peter Fallon, Gallery Press collection contain extensive files of correspondence spanning 1968-1998. The largest part of this correspondence is located in Series 2, though most correspondence directly related to books published by the Gallery Press is located in subseries 1.1; submissions correspondence may also be located in subseries 1.2; some correspondence related to Deerfield Press, O'Brien Press, and Oldcastle Enterprises and After Hours Books is located in subseries 1.3, 1.4, and 1.5, respectively; correspondence related to works edited by Peter Fallon is generally located in subseries 3.2; and letters regarding Fallon's lecture tours of the United States and Japan are ordinarily located in subseries 3.3. Peter Fallon generally filed his correspondence according to subject such as "correspondence" or "Business correspondence" although he maintained alphabatized files for letters from friends, colleagues, and dignitaries.

This series attempts to maintain these systems of filing. Therefore, subseries 2.1 contains general correspondence organized by date. This correspondence includes fan mail as well as correspondence with friends, literary and artistic figures, and business contacts (including other publishers). Subseries 2.2 contains correspondence that is alphabetically arranged. While the majority of this is personal correspondence between Fallon and other writers and musicians, some of this correspondence is related to works that Fallon edited for Gallery or other presses. There are also a very few submissions. Please note that all correspondence with Seamus Heaney, including personal correspondence, is restricted and is located in box 86 of subseries 1.1. Business correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (2.1) General correspondence, (2.2) Literary correspondence, and (2.3) Business correspondence.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Subseries 2.2., Letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order, with restricted correspondence at the end.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Subseries 2.2., Letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of the literary and personal papers of Peter Fallon from ca. 1968-1998. The papers include writings by Peter Fallon including manuscripts and typescripts of his poetry, prose, music and plays; works edited by Fallon; materials relating to his appearances including lectures, speeches, interviews, and readings by Fallon; the printed material consists mostly of reviews of Fallon's work and copies of periodicals in which his works appeared.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (3.1) Writings by Peter Fallon, (3.2) Works edited by Peter Fallon, (3.3) Appearances by Peter Fallon, (3.4) Printed material, and (3.5) Appointment books and calendars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of subject files relating to Gallery Press from 1977-1996. The subject files include materials relating to Gallery Press anniversaries, literary awards, organizations relating to literature and the arts in Ireland, and information on other publishers. Of particular interest are materials relating to Tara Telephone, the publishing predecessor to Gallery Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of printed material produced mainly by Gallery Press from 1960s-1990s. The materials include publicity files created for particular works published by Gallery Press, as well as general promotional materials for Gallery Press including catalogues, press releases and flyers for readings by authors. Also included general printed materials including newspaper clippings and catalogues of other publishers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (5.1) Publicity files by authors, (5.2) Gallery Press promotional materials, and (5.3) General printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of photographs of Peter Fallon, Fallon and family, and Fallon with various authors and poets. There are also publicity photographs of Gallery Press authors and a set of photographs by Mike Bunn for The Writers: A Sense of Ireland published by O'Brien Press. These photographs are denoted as (O'Brien).
